Philip, thank you or your comments.  It's really helpful to hear 
thoughts =
like yours at this early stage of research.  I'll try to 
address some of y=
our questions.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <ptucker@...> =
wrote:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> I just finished reading your paper.  Cool stuff.  I=
t's exciting to 
see
> you expand NEAT in such a novel way.  I have a few c=
omments and 
questions.
> 
> 1) I agree there is intuitive appeal to the CP=
PN scheme.  The way
> subtle elaborations are applied to core structure see=
ms powerful.  
But
> I can't see what the next step from here is - specific=
ally, to 
produce
> an ANN.  
> The examples in the paper produce 2D greysc=
ale images.  Do you 
already
> have ideas how a CPPN would produce a direct=
ed network graph with
> connection weights?  I suppose one simple scheme wo=
uld be to 
interpret
> the X and Y inputs as neuron IDs, and the output as =
the connection
> weight between those IDs.  The range and density of neuron=
 IDs 
would
> need to be represented somehow.  Does that seem lik the right=
 
track? 

That is one way that might lead to interesting results, although=
 the 
downside is that it views the network as being fully connected, 
whic=
h could get expensive for large networks.  But your proposed 
method is nic=
e in the sense that it could create complex patterns of 
weights.

I think =
the bigger answer is that there are numerous ways to use 
generic patterns =
to specify weighted connected graphs.  We (myself 
and my students) do have=
 some in mind that I believe will be 
powerful.  One thing to remember is t=
hat neural connections groups 
in biology also ultimately rely on chemical =
gradients.  It's true 
I'm not giving you a complete answer since I don't w=
ant to hype a 
potential method until it's been at least tested a little, b=
ut we 
definitely have some methods in mind.  We spent a research group 
br=
ainstorming session on this one topic.

> Do you envision CPPNs with multip=
le outputs?
> 

Yes, for sure.  As you are anticipating, it will be helpful=
 to have 
multiple correlated patterns for certain kinds of domains, likely=
 
including weighted connected graphs.

> 2) Can you give a short definitio=
n of "gradient" and "coordinate
> frames" in the context of the paper?  The=
y're used several times, 
and
> I think I have the general idea from contex=
t.  But they are 
pivotal to
> this domain, so I want to make sure I have a=
 clear understanding.
> 

This is a good question because it suggests the t=
ech report may 
benefit from some more clarification on these definitions. =
 By 
gradient I mean a gradually shifting chemical concentration over 
phys=
ical space. The simplest gradient would be a chemical that is 
highly conce=
ntrated at one side but that gradually becomes less and 
less concentrated =
as you move towards the other side.   But gradient 
patterns can take almos=
t any form, such as periodic concentrations 
that go up and down several ti=
mes.

Coordinate frame means all the variables that specify positional 
inf=
ormation that are available to higher-level functions.  So in 2D, 
x and y =
are a minimal coordinate frame.  But you also might have x, 
y, and d (dist=
ance from center).  Or, you could have only x and d, 
but no y.  The coordi=
nate frame profoundly biases the kinds of 
patterns a function within that =
frame might output.  For example, if 
the coordinate frame is sin(x) and y,=
 then it is highly likely that 
any function within this coordinate frame w=
ill output a pattern that 
is periodic along x.  

Gradients relate to coor=
dinate frames in that in biological 
organisms, the coordinate frames are s=
pecified by chemical gradients.

> 3) You list repetition, repetition with =
variation, symmetry, 
imperfect
> symmetry, elaborated regularity, and pres=
ervation of regularity as 
the
> 6 patterns exhibited in nature that a good=
 model should include. 
> Other than your own intuition, is there any justi=
fication for this
> being a necessary and complete list?
> 

I need to put =
up my paper on this topic that I just presented at the 
GECCO workshop on d=
evelopment (it should go up soon).  This was the 
exact question I was tryi=
ng to address.  The question is not so much 
whether it's just my intuition=
, but rather what else one could go 
on?  It seemed to go over pretty well =
with the community that these 
are critical features to look for.

I would =
not argue that the list is complete, but it is certainly 
necessary.  Can y=
ou imagine an encoding being able to evolve 
anything with near biology com=
plexity without these properties?  For 
example, imagine an encoding that c=
annot produce repetition, or one 
that can't produce imperfect symmetry.  I=
'd argue that it's clear 
without the need for further evidence that such e=
ncodings would be 
too limited to achieve anything superior.

There are pos=
sibly other critical features as well, but I think this 
list a good start =
since you rarely find an encoding that can even 
display all these features=
.


> 4) I'm skeptical of the human-guided evolution process you used 
with=

> evolutionary art.  It seems like you're arguing that an important 
step
=
> on the path to evolving a bird is to evolve a bird-shaped picture. 
> But=
 birds weren't selected because somebody thought they looked 
like
> birds,=
 they were selected mostly based on behavior.  
> You mention 2 other schem=
es (L-Systems and Turing's "reaction
> diffusion model") that produced orga=
nic-looking structures.  Those
> were both around 50 years ago (I think), a=
nd they haven't (as far 
as I
> know) led to serious biologically-inspired =
computer systems.
> 

In contrast to you, I think the interactive approach =
makes a strong 
analogy to how birds evolved- stronger than any other.  The=
 reason 
is that birds evolved, like humans, from flatworms.  Flatworms, wh=
en 
they were new, were not being "evaluated" for their similarity to 
bird=
s, either behaviorally or morphologically.  Likewise, they were 
not evalua=
ted for their human-ness either.  Rather, flatworms 
were "evaluated" in th=
eir local context for what they could do at 
the time, given the current si=
tuation on earth hundreds of millions 
of years ago.

Interactive evolution=
 is analogous because when I choose a picture I 
am not comparing it to an =
ultimate target (like bird or human) but 
rather evaluating it relative to =
the current context it is in.  I am 
saying, this has the most promising pr=
operties right now.  I might 
choose a blob-like picture simply because it =
is symmetric and I know 
that I want symmetry down the line.  Even though i=
t looks nothing 
like a spaceship (or bird, or human), it has good properti=
es in its 
present day, just like the flatworm.  Benchmarks do not work lik=
e 
that.  So I think the behavioral/morphological dimension is 
orthogonal =
to the issue of the non-target-based selectivity of 
natural evolution.  As=
 you say in a later point, there is no final 
solution in mind in natural e=
volution.  Likewise in interactive 
evolution.

> 5) You draw a strong dich=
otomy between CPPNs and develompental
> processes because CPPNs aren't time=
-based.  But, the CPPN network 
is
> going to have to be activated, and eac=
h step is going to take 
time. 
> Also, one could view the model as having =
one of the inputs be 
time. 
> It can be very fast, but a gene regulatory n=
etwork in a computer is
> much faster than a biological one.  Am I missing =
something here?
> 

A CPPN need only compute an output once for each coordi=
nate.  A GRN, 
on the other hand, must continually send information back an=
d forth 
across multiple coordinates.  That means that each coordinate in t=
he 
phenotype instantiates multiple computations, whereas in a CPPN each 
c=
oordinate only instantiates once.  The question is not about the 
complexit=
y of simulating a single GRN vs. a single NN (both are 
likely similar), bu=
t rather about how many times that GRN or that NN 
must be fully-activated =
for each coordinate/cell in the phenotype.

Also, I'm not sure about what y=
ou mean by "one could view the model 
as having one of the inputs be time."=
  I don't see the meaning of 
that view when the only inputs are coordinate=
 frames like x and y.  
How could x be considered time?  Of course, one cou=
ld simply say 
that one input is x and the other is time, so that the whole=
 pattern 
is viewed as "how x changes over time," but the CPPN formalism do=
es 
not have any need or interpretation for such a view.  It simply 
produc=
es a pattern on its output(s).

> 6) This is a semantic nitpick.  You write=
 in paragraph 4 of section
> 2.3, "[biological evolution] does not start se=
arching in a space of
> the same complexity as the final solution".  Descri=
bing evolution 
as
> having a "final solution" is misleading - it makes it =
seem 
directed. 
> There is no final solution, there are just solutions goo=
d enough to
> survive.
> 

Yes true, this point is right.  I was just tryin=
g to be more 
concise.  It would be more wordy and perhaps confusing to say=
 
that "biological evolution did not start search in a space of the 
same c=
omplexity as the current successful phenotypes."  However, 
that is what I =
meant.

Thanks again for the comments.  I'm very happy to discuss this topi=
c.

ken
